children: Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer and second most common cause of cancer-related mortality among men and women in the United States. There are approximately 145,600 new cases in the United States annually, and lifetime risk for colorectal cancer is 4.5% for men and 4.1% for women.

The incidence and mortality for colorectal cancer have decreased over the past 30 years because of changes in risk factors (e.g., decreased smoking) and early detection. However, the number of colorectal cancer cases in patients younger than 50 years has steadily increased for unknown reasons. Survival rates exceed 90% with localized disease, underscoring the importance of early detection. Between 20% and 53% of adults older than 50 years have premalignant colon adenomas detected on screening, and 3% to 8% of the adenomas have advanced histologic features. Despite strong evidence supporting colorectal cancer screening, only about 63% of Americans older than 50 years are up to date for recommended testing.
The number of colorectal cancer cases in patients younger than 50 years is increasing.

Colorectal cancer develops through one of three mechanisms: chromosomal instability, microsatellite instability, and hypermethylation of tumor suppressor genes.

Chromosomal instability is the most common mechanism, accounting for approximately 85% of colorectal cancers. Chromosomal instability is characterized by abnormal cells that gain or lose whole or large fractions of chromosomes (aneuploidy) at an increased rate compared with normal cells. Stepwise accumulation of mutations leads to progression from normal colon to adenoma to cancer. The most commonly mutated gene in this pathway is the adenomatous polyposis coli (

Microsatellites are dozens to hundreds of repetitive nucleotide sequences seen throughout the human genome. The term

refers to mismatched bases at repeated DNA microsatellites. Microsatellite instability accounts for about 15% of colorectal cancers and is characterized by defective DNA mismatch repair, leading to multiple mutations, adenomas, and cancer. The third mechanism involves hypermethylation of tumor suppressor genes and the development of serrated lesions and cancer. Serrated lesions are a heterogeneous group of lesions classified by their sawtooth appearance on histology. They are often found in the proximal colon and may be flat and difficult to distinguish from normal mucosa

Colorectal cancer develops through one of three mechanisms: chromosomal instability, microsatellite instability, and hypermethylation of tumor suppressor genes; chromosomal instability is the most common mechanism, accounting for 85% of cases.

Nonmodifiable risk factors for colon cancer include age (≥45 years), male sex, and personal or family history of colon adenomas or colorectal cancer. The risk doubles with a family history of colorectal cancer in a first-degree relative.

Long-standing (≥8 years) colonic inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis) is associated with about a 2.7-fold increased risk; the risk depends on the severity and extent of bowel involvement. Patients with ureterocolic anastomoses after bladder surgery and adult survivors of childhood malignancy who received abdominal radiation are also at increased risk for colorectal cancer.

Modifiable risk factors include diets high in red and processed meat; low intake of fruits, vegetables, fiber, and dairy; use of alcohol and tobacco; type 2 diabetes mellitus; sedentary lifestyle; and obesity.
Nonmodifiable risk factors for colorectal cancer include age (≥45 years), male sex, and personal or family history of colorectal cancer.

Modifiable risk factors for colorectal cancer include diets high in red and processed meat; low intake of fruits, vegetables, fiber, and dairy; use of alcohol and tobacco; type 2 diabetes mellitus; sedentary lifestyle; and obesity.

Substantial epidemiologic and experimental data suggest that aspirin prevents colorectal cancer. Cohort and case-control studies, for example, show that aspirin use is associated with a 30% decreased risk for colorectal cancer. Randomized controlled trials, however, have shown that aspirin decreases the risk for recurrent adenomas but has less clear benefit in preventing colorectal cancer. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force updated their guidelines in 2015 to include the use of low-dose aspirin (81 mg/d) for preventing colorectal cancer and cardiovascular disease in individuals aged 50 to 59 years who are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease, have a life expectancy of 10 years, and are willing to take aspirin for 10 years. for a more detailed discussion of aspirin use in primary prevention.

Studies of other NSAIDs for prevention of colon cancer and adenomas have also yielded positive results; however, benefits of aspirin and other NSAIDs must be weighed against harms, especially gastrointestinal bleeding.

Some evidence suggests that selective cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors prevent recurrent adenomas and decrease the incidence of advanced lesions; however, the associated increased cardiovascular risk confounds a recommendation of their use for chemoprevention.

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends the use of low-dose aspirin for preventing colorectal cancer and cardiovascular disease in individuals aged 50 to 59 years who are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease.

Because adenomas are an intermediary step in the progression from normal colonic mucosa to colon cancer, identification and management of adenomatous polyps are critical. Adenomas can be found throughout the colon. They are classified by morphology, histology, and degree of dysplasia

. Adenomas with any degree of villous histology or high-grade dysplasia have greater malignant potential. Risk is also increased in polyps larger than 1 cm. The progression of adenoma to carcinoma takes approximately 8 to 10 years.

Key quality indicators for screening colonoscopy include adequate bowel preparation, preparation sufficient to identify polyps 6 mm or larger, visualization of the entire colon to the cecum, adenoma detection rate, and longer duration of colonoscopy.
Screening colonoscopy is recommended to begin at age 40 years or 10 years earlier than the age of the youngest first-degree relative diagnosed with colorectal cancer before age 60 years.
Colorectal cancer screening is recommended to begin at age 40 years for any patient with two first-degree relatives diagnosed with colorectal cancer after age 60 years.
Colonoscopy is recommended for patients with Lynch syndrome at age 20 to 25 years or 10 years earlier than youngest age at which cancer was diagnosed in the family.

Colorectal cancer may be asymptomatic or may present with iron deficiency anemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, altered bowel habits, abdominal pain, colonic obstruction, and weight loss in more advanced cases.

Colorectal cancer is usually diagnosed by colonoscopy with biopsy. Staging is based on tumor size and extent of invasion into local tissues, lymph node involvement, and evidence of metastasis (TNM system). Cross-sectional imaging of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is used for staging in the initial evaluation after diagnosis. Favorable characteristics include stage I to II cancer and lack of angiolymphatic involvement. Endoscopic resection of polyps can be curative, and negative margins after removal are a favorable sign. Malignant sessile or flat polyps are associated with higher risk for recurrence and local or distant spread.

Several hereditary syndromes are associated with colorectal cancer
Lynch syndrome is characterized by germline mutations in the mismatch repair genes (
) or the epithelial cell adhesion molecule gene (

), leading to an increased risk for neoplasia of the colon and other organs. The previous name for this syndrome, hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, is no longer used because the syndrome is associated with colorectal polyps as well as extracolonic cancers. The syndrome follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, and new mutations are rare.

In persons with Lynch syndrome, the lifetime risk for colorectal cancer depends on the location of the gene mutation; the risk can be as high as 50% to 80%. Colorectal cancer in Lynch syndrome is more likely in the proximal colon and can display characteristic pathologic features, such as tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes and medullary growth pattern. Colorectal tumors in Lynch syndrome result from microsatellite instability that can be assessed using polymerase chain reaction or immunohistochemistry (see
). All colorectal cancers should be screened for Lynch syndrome genetic mutations or microsatellite instability.

Lynch syndrome should be suspected in patients with synchronous (occurring within 6 months of the primary tumor diagnosis) or metachronous (occurring more than 6 months after the primary tumor diagnosis) colorectal cancers, colorectal cancer before age 50 years, occurrence of multiple Lynch syndrome–associated cancers, or a family history of multiple cancers associated with Lynch syndrome. Clinical criteria to evaluate for Lynch syndrome include the Amsterdam and Bethesda criteria
as well as newer models, such as the PREdiction Model for gene Mutations 5 (PREMM

). The Amsterdam II criteria are specific but not sensitive for the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome, whereas the Bethesda criteria have good sensitivity but poor specificity. Given the limitations of the clinical criteria and predictive models, genetic counseling and testing should be offered to patients with a personal and/or family history consistent with Lynch syndrome as well as to patients whose tumor shows evidence of microsatellite instability or loss of mismatch repair protein expression. When a mutation is identified in a family, first-degree relatives should be tested and surveillance instituted.

. Risk-reducing total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy should be considered starting at age 40 to 45 years after childbearing is completed in women who carry Lynch syndrome mutations.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an inherited disorder characterized by multiple (usually >100) adenomatous colon polyps. FAP is caused by germline
mutations that are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, although

mutations occur in about 25% of cases. Adenomas in classic FAP are more numerous in the distal colon than in the proximal colon. Adenoma and cancer develop in 100% of classic FAP cases if surgery is not performed. The average age of colorectal cancer onset is 39 years, with a risk of 93% by age 50 years. An attenuated form of FAP (AFAP) causes fewer polyps (<100 synchronous polyps) with more proximal colonic distribution. The risk for colon cancer in patients with AFAP is about 70% by age 80 years, with an average age at onset of 58 years.
Both FAP and AFAP are associated with extracolonic intestinal manifestations

. Duodenal adenomas require surveillance because the lifetime risk for duodenal adenocarcinoma is estimated at 4%. Fundic gland polyps of the stomach do not have malignant potential but can mask the presence of gastric adenomas and cancer; risk for gastric cancer is less than 1%. Patients are also at risk for desmoid tumors, especially after abdominal surgery, and for papillary thyroid cancer. Nonmalignant findings include extra teeth, sebaceous or epidermoid cysts, osteomas, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmented epithelium.

In classic FAP mutation carriers, screening with sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy should begin at age 10 to 12 years and be repeated every 1 to 2 years. Screening in patients with AFAP can be delayed until age 20 to 25 years and should be performed with colonoscopy. For individuals with FAP and AFAP, screening with upper endoscopy should begin at age 25 to 30 years and include visualization of the papilla with a duodenoscope. Fundic gland polyps in the stomach should be randomly sampled. Surveillance of the upper gastrointestinal tract is determined by duodenal findings. Annual thyroid ultrasonography is also recommended.

Colectomy is the treatment of choice for classic FAP and may be pursued in patients with AFAP. Absolute indications for surgery include cancer and significant symptoms, such as rectal bleeding. Relative indications include multiple adenomas greater than 6 mm; an increase in the number of polyps; adenoma with high-grade dysplasia; and multiple diminutive polyps, which can prevent identification of adenomas. The type of surgery depends on the polyp burden in the rectum. High rectal polyp burden typically necessitates total proctocolectomy with ileostomy or ileal anal pouch; otherwise, subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomoses may be possible. Postsurgical surveillance is yearly sigmoidoscopy for patients with an intact rectum and ileoscopy every 2 years for those with an ileostomy.
-associated polyposis (MAP) is an inherited syndrome characterized by fewer adenomas than classic FAP. MAP is caused by mutations in the

gene, a component of base excision repair. In this recessive condition, affected patients inherited two mutated copies from their parents. Most patients have 20 to 99 adenomatous colon polyps. Some individuals can develop cancer with only a few or no synchronous adenomas. Mean age at cancer onset is about 52 years. In addition, patients with MAP can have other polyp types, including serrated lesions and hyperplastic polyps. Duodenal cancer risk in MAP is estimated at 4%, and surveillance with upper endoscopy is similar to that indicated in patients with FAP. Surgical management of the colon is also similar to that of FAP.

Several recently described rare polyposis syndromes are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. Polymerase proofreading–associated polyposis appears to have features of both FAP and Lynch syndrome and is caused by mutations in polymerase proofreading genes
. Endometrial cancer has been described in this syndrome, and tumor testing shows microsatellite instability. Mutations in
have also been associated with hereditary polyposis. Management guidelines are not established, but management of colonic polyps follows similar principles as for other adenomatous polyp syndromes.

Hamartomas are polyps caused by overgrowth of normal tissue. Three primary syndromes are associated with hamartomas in the gastrointestinal tract: juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS), Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), and
hamartoma syndrome (also known as Cowden syndrome).
JPS is caused by mutations in the
genes. Its incidence is approximately 1 in 130,000 live births. Multiple juvenile polyps (>5 polyps) are found in the colon (98%), stomach (14%), and small bowel (14%) of patients with JPS
. Sporadic juvenile polyps can be found in up to 1% of children and are not considered syndromic. The average age at JPS diagnosis is 18.5 years, and rectal bleeding is the most common symptom.
PJS is caused by mutations in the
gene. Its incidence is approximately 1 in 200,000 live births. PJS hamartomas are found primarily in the small bowel but can also develop in the stomach and colon
. PJS is also characterized by hyperpigmented mucocutaneous macules on the lips and buccal mucosa
. Small-bowel hamartomas develop at a young age in patients with PJS and may present with intussusception, obstruction, and bleeding.
hamartoma syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the tumor suppressor gene
. Macrocephaly and characteristic benign skin findings are common, including facial trichilemmomas, lipomas, and oral papillomas.

Serrated polyposis syndrome is characterized by numerous serrated polyps in the colon and an increased risk for colon cancer. The definition is based on having either of the following over the patient's lifetime:
Five or more serrated polyps proximal to the rectum, all at least 5 mm and with two or more at least 10 mm
More than 20 serrated polyps throughout the colon, at least five located proximal to the rectum

Estimates suggest that the prevalence of serrated polyposis syndrome is 0.3% to 0.6%. The genetic basis of the syndrome is unknown, although smoking appears to be a risk factor. Colonoscopy is recommended every 1 to 3 years with removal of all polyps greater than 5 mm. Surgery may be considered if the polyps cannot be managed endoscopically. No extracolonic manifestations have been noted in serrated polyposis syndrome.
Lynch syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the mismatch repair genes and carries a lifetime risk for colorectal cancer of 50% to 80%.

Lynch syndrome should be suspected in patients with synchronous or metachronous colorectal cancers, colorectal cancer before 50 years of age, occurrence of multiple Lynch syndrome–associated cancers, or family history of multiple cancers associated with Lynch syndrome.
Colectomy is the treatment of choice for classic familial adenomatous polyposis and may be pursued in patients with the attenuated form of the disease.
